item.title: Comment on How important is “the scientific method”? by How about favoring strict definitions first?
item.description:
First, discoveries need not use anything at all, much less the scientific method, to be originated, Such as someone like Einstein performing his thought experiments . However, confirming those discoveries most definitely used the scientific method in all its rigorous glory.

"A hallmark of Albert Einstein's career was his use of visualized thought experiments as a fundamental tool for understanding physical issues and for elucidating his concepts to others. Einstein's thought experiments took diverse forms. In his youth, he mentally chased beams of light. For special relativity, he employed moving trains and flashes of lightning to explain his most penetrating insights. For general relativity, he considered a person falling off a roof, accelerating elevators, blind beetles crawling on curved surfaces and the like. "

"A thought experiment is a logical argument or mental model cast within the context of an imaginary (hypothetical or even counterfactual) scenario. A scientific thought experiment, in particular, may examine the implications of a theory, law, or set of principles with the aid of fictive and/or natural particulars (demons sorting molecules, cats whose lives hinge upon a radioactive disintegration, men in enclosed elevators) in an idealized environment (massless trapdoors, absence of friction). They describe experiments that, except for some specific and necessary idealizations, could conceivably be performed in the real world.

As opposed to physical experiments, thought experiments do not report new empirical data."

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/how-important-is-the-scientific-method.html?commentID=160760302

Post URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/how-important-is-the-scientific-method.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=how-important-is-the-scientific-method

Votes: 232⬆ 0⬇

item.title: Comment on How important is “the scientific method”? by Jeremy Fox
item.description:
Leaving aside any other issues with the paper, framing the result as an argument for methodological pluralism is a little odd. "75% of Nobel Prize winners recommend the scientific method" seems like a pretty good advertisement for the scientific method! It's quite close to those old ads for Trident sugar-free gum, that claimed Trident was recommended by "four out of five dentists."

item.title: Comment on Wednesday assorted links by The Midnight Narwhals with Bacon
item.description:
Reply to Blackthorne:

Re 1: I imagine the spatial distribution of native americans is playing a role here. They have a much higher suicide rate and make up a larger % of the population in many of those states (https://worldpopulationreview.com/state-rankings/native-american-population). Still doesn't seem like it explains everything

This. You see the same thing among native populations in Alaska, Greenland, and the Northern Territories.

item.title: Comment on Wednesday assorted links by No slippery slopes in Germany
item.description:
Reply to steve:

#2- In the case of unavoidable harm the Swedes seem to have a preference for preserving the life of the pedestrian over the car passengers. First, I wonder if Americans would survey the same way. Second, will the purchasers of self driving cars be happy if they know the algorithm favors the pedestrian?

Steve

Of course they do. Europeans consider walking (and in a number of countries, bicycling) in their neighborhoods a normal activity, from young children to the elderly. Car driving is a relatively new social change in societies that were exclusively pedestrian (except for a few horses) a century and a half ago. America is a true outlier in this regard, for a variety of reasons.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/wednesday-assorted-links-454.html?commentID=160760254

item.title: Comment on The Left on FDA Peer Approval by blue jay
item.description:
Reply to Naveen K:

I had the same question on why some company won't evergreen ambroxol so I asked GPT-4:

Challenges and Considerations
Cost of Development and Approval: The process of modifying the drug and conducting the necessary clinical trials is expensive and time-consuming. For a generic drug like ambroxol, the return on investment might be questionable unless the new version offers significant advantages over the original.

Market Competition: There are already several mucolytic agents available in the U.S. market. Introducing a slightly modified version of ambroxol might not be enough to guarantee substantial market share, especially if healthcare providers and patients are already satisfied with existing treatments.

Regulatory Hurdles: The FDA has stringent requirements for approving new drugs or modified versions of existing drugs. The company would need to demonstrate that the new version is safe and effective, which requires robust clinical data. The FDA might not grant approval if the modifications are deemed too minor or if the benefits over the original are not clear.

Profitability Concerns: Since ambroxol is cheap and widely available as a generic in other markets, pricing the new version competitively while recouping development costs could be challenging.

Keeping in mind, of course, that GPT-4 makes up bullshit all the time and is generally unreliable.

But it's interesting that it says "There are already several mucolytic agents available in the U.S. market. " Is that true? If so...why do we have this column?

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/the-left-on-fda-peer-approval.html?commentID=160760047

item.title: Comment on The Left on FDA Peer Approval by blue jay
item.description:
Reply to Luka:

The left are really weird when it comes to what kind of substances they think we should and should not be allowed to use. Some want to legalize all recreational drugs, even heroin. The logic tends to be an emphasis on our personal freedom and the racist harm of the drug war. At the same time they hate modern medicine and "Big Pharma" (except COVID-19 vaccines) and won't speed up approval of something as banal as sunscreens already legal in other rich nations. There is a strong tendency to want to regulate new drugs, medicines, and even food for our "safety" or even ban them. They're willing to trust adults to take meth but not necessarily a novel new pain or heart medication because it might be dangerous.

Before anyone jumps in with a "What about the Republicans????", I know they have their own set of problems, I'm just trying to figure out leftist logic on this. What exactly are their priorities? It seems to follow Bryan Caplan's belief that the left is basically motivated by a distaste for markets. They just don't like the idea of a corporation creating new pharmaceuticals and making money off of it.

"They just don't like the idea of a [corporation, company or person] creating [anything] and making money off of it."

They don't like profit, but they especially don't like anything that would make one [person, corporation] earn more than another, bcz that shatters the belief that we're all just different color M&Ms and that blue, green red and yellow must be distributed proportionally across the cookie according to some natural law.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/the-left-on-fda-peer-approval.html?commentID=160760041

item.title: Comment on The Left on FDA Peer Approval by blue jay
item.description:
Reply to Naveen K:

Alex already mentions the chemical principle is entirely different. Ambroxol reduces mucus viscosity and increases surfactant production, while acetylcysteine breaks disulfide bonds in mucoproteins, and guaifenesin increases mucus hydration to ease expulsion.

You say: "Ambroxol reduces mucus viscosity "
Chat says: "There are already several mucolytic agents available in the U.S. market. "

"Mucolytics...break up mucus in your lungs and make it easier to cough out. "

So, what you're saying is that "Ambroxol " is not a "mucolytic " agent, but some other kind of chemical. OK, got it. But GPT doesn't make that clear so it's not clear it knows the difference.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/the-left-on-fda-peer-approval.html?commentID=160760074

item.title: Comment on What are your favorite non-violent movies? by Marc
item.description:
When my son was rather young (middle school?) and becoming too enamored with (a) entertainment violence, (b) glorified violence AND my wife was out of town for several days...we watched Full Metal Jacket, Hamburger Hill, Platoon, Deer Hunter and Born on the Fourth of July over one weekend...with only a comedic break for Good Morning Vietnam.

As a small sample empirical exercise, that made him non-violent quite efficiently!
